comment: /* Participated Ukrainian teams in the Soviet Cup by regions */
llm_output:
The change made is "Updated team participation years for various football clubs in Ukraine." 

Not Weaponised. The changes appear to be factual updates regarding the historical participation of football teams, without any language that suggests a political or cultural narrative.

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -568,7 +568,7 @@
 ==Professional clubs in Ukraine==
 The professional football in Ukraine has developed its traditions within the Soviet Union republican and All-Union competitions. As the other clubs of the former Soviet Union football, it has transitioned from cities' competitions to competitions among teams of masters' which was a Soviet conditional term for professional teams. For amateur teams following the [[World War II]], there was established a separate term, collective [teams] of physical culture [enthusiasts] or KFK (CPhC). 
 
-During 1989-1992 almost all teams of masters' have transitioned to football clubs, sports clubs or other sports-based organizations. The reason for the transition was switch from [[command economy]] of the Soviet Union to normal [[free market]]-driven economy.
+During 1989-1992 almost all teams of masters' have transitioned to football clubs, sports clubs or other sports-based organizations. The reason for the transition was switch from [[command economy]] of the Soviet Union to normal [[free market]]-driven economy. Some clubs have separate from their parent sports organizations such as [[FC Dynamo Kyiv|Dynamo Kyiv]] (from [[Dynamo (Ukraine)|Dynamo]] of Ukraine) or [[FC Shakhtar Donetsk|Shakhtar Donetsk]], others were re-established anew such as [[FC Karpaty Lviv|Karpaty Lviv]].
 
 ==Ukrainian clubs in the Soviet competitions==
 ===Ukrainian medalists of the Soviet first tier competitions===
llm_output:
The change made is an addition of context regarding the transition of football clubs in Ukraine, specifically mentioning that some clubs separated from their parent sports organizations and providing examples like Dynamo Kyiv and Shakhtar Donetsk, while also noting that others were re-established anew, such as Karpaty Lviv.

Not Weaponised. The addition provides historical context about the evolution of football clubs in Ukraine without employing weaponised language or narratives that could be seen as politically charged or divisive.

llm_output:
The change made in this revision is the addition of several football teams and their historical details, specifically for the regions of Donetsk, Dnipropetrovsk, Luhansk, and others, as well as adjustments to the number of teams listed for Kyiv and other regions.

**Added teams and historical details for Donetsk, Dnipropetrovsk, Luhansk, and other regions. Adjusted team counts for Kyiv and others.**

Not Weaponised. The changes primarily involve factual updates regarding sports teams and do not contain language or narratives that could be interpreted as weaponising cultural heritage.

comment: /* Participated Ukrainian teams in the Soviet Cup by regions */
llm_output:
The change made in this revision is the addition of citation markers (e.g., {49}, {4}, {2}) to various football teams listed in the article. 

**Weaponised**: The context of the revision, along with the user comment, suggests an attempt to provide more detailed sourcing for the historical context of Ukrainian football teams, which can be seen as an effort to reinforce the legitimacy of Ukrainian cultural heritage in the face of ongoing geopolitical tensions. This aligns with narratives that emphasize the importance of Ukrainian identity and history, particularly in relation to Russian narratives.

Added sections detailing "Ukrainian clubs in the Soviet competitions," including medalists and all-time tables for various tiers.

Not Weaponised. The content focuses on historical sports achievements without invoking any political or cultural narratives that could be seen as weaponising cultural heritage.
